Description: Body sherd (mended from three fragments, including 1888,0601.468.h) of Chian Wild Goat Style or Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black, mostly lost; exterior, from top: trace of hook maeander pattern; wide and narrow bands; lotus bud and flower frieze.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1888,0601.468.h and belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1912.32a(14) which Lemos identifies as a vase belonging to the group of vases with floral decoration in the Chalice Style. The lotus flower and bud pattern found on these vessels appears on the exterior surface of the vases and in the later vases the pattern resembles that found on Fikellura vases. However, the same pattern also features on the cul of Wild Goat Style chalices, to which this sherd bears closer similarities. See Lemos no. 114 from Emporio. Whilst the heavy chalice does not typically appear as early as in the Wild Goat Style, the thickness of this sherd suggests that it comes from a vessel much larger than a chalice. Perhaps this sherd marks a transition from the Wild Goat Style to the Mature Animal Style.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1532) (phase 2)
